Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Respond promptly to emergency calls and reach the scene as quickly as possible
Situation2: The ambulance driver is on standby at the station, ready for any new dispatch to come in.
Story: I sat in the ambulance, tapping my fingers on the steering wheel, my mind drifting to the family dinner scheduled for tonight. My parents had called earlier, reminding me how important it was to be there—especially this year, with my grandmother’s health declining. They spoke of tradition, of the meal we always shared, and how my presence would mean everything. I promised I’d make it, but as I glanced at the radio, I knew any moment it could crackle to life with an emergency call. My duty as an ambulance driver was clear: when the call came, I had to go, no matter what. The weight of both roles pressed on me. My family expected me to honor our customs, to be the devoted son, while my job demanded I be ready to save lives at a moment’s notice. I felt torn, anxiety twisting in my chest, knowing that soon I might have to choose between the people I love and the people who might need me most.
